ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: new ways to think about human-nature interactions and dependencies, cool pieces of knowledge about topics ranging from fish markets to panda diplomacy
I greatly enjoyed this course because it gave me a different lens on East Asia that helped round out the historical knowledge I acquired over the course of my time Yale.

This is my first history class at Yale and the approach to history is really different from high school. Really interesting course that goes into the intersection of history and environment and humans and animals. Showed me that history is really complex and more interesting than I thought
Understanding how history papers work, and gaining an introduction to the field of Environmental History.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: As someone with no background in east Asian history, it was always helpful to have mini lectures before seminar discussions to give some more context.

strengths: cool topics
weaknesses: not enough discussion (It would have been nice to have more student discussions in big group, not breakout rooms. It's always awkward at first, but throughout the semester, people usually get more comfortable talking, and I think that's where the coolest conversations happen.); background info power-points dragged sometimes

This course was incredibly well taught in that it covered a wide variety of natural histories including that of animals and agriculture. It also examined the broader societal implications of natural history.
Only met once a week for a long time I wouldve preferred more sessions shorter time.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Frank's use of a variety of visual tools beyond just typical PowerPoints helped create a meaningful learning experience.
It was really tiring to sit through so much zoom.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, it's a cool class for people interested in the intersections between environment and history, and the workload is reasonable
I would recommend this to anyone who seeks to understand the natural undercurrents which dictate East Asian History.
I would definitely recommend this course! Dr. Frank is very knowledgable and kind, as well as deeply engaged with the subject matter.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
